doc/source/2104.rst.message:
Suggested wording:

The hacluster charm has a new action: ``update-ring``.

When a clustered application (working alongside the hacluster application) is scaled down (i.e. ``remove-unit``) nodes in the corosync ring will not be removed. The ``update-ring`` action performs the removal and updates the corosync configuration accordingly. Failure to run this action will leave the cluster in an "incomplete" state. The corosync ring does not need to be updated when scaling up; it is automatically extended. See the `hacluster charm`_ README for more information.

build-tools/yum-builddep-wrapper.message: The -z check is there to protect the grep, but we're also going to end up calling a non-existent yum-builddep at line 11. Which seems odd, because we now know it doesn't exist.
The idea is for "command not found" error to show up as a side effect.
Consider using getopt for parsing cmdline options to avoid the special handling for =

I don't think getopt can deal with unexpected options -- I would have to spell out every single option that yum-buildep supports. If you know how to make getopt skip over unexpected options, let me know.

I guess this is intended to be on volatile fs, but if ROOT_PREFIX is set, it probably won't be. So the potential exists for this file to be persisted over a reboot, for example, such as if a power failure occurs. Do we need some check at the beginning of a script to check this file and ensure its pid matches a running yum process?

Isn't that why you're doing this update, though? Because the yum.pid existed, and contained a valid PID that was a different process and so the build hangs? My point was that this code prevents that from happening as long as this code is reached, but does nothing for the case where this wrapper was killed prior to reaching this point. Maybe I misunderstood the issue you're addressing.

You are right, but I can't easily tell whether the PID refers to a real lock owner, or it's a random coincidence. Other than looking at PID's command line, I suppose, something like "/usr/bin/python* ... <any_script_that_may_conceivably_use_yum_modules> ..." That seems difficult to detect reliably.

I don't think we need anything else.
If yum.pid exists at the beginning, and refers to a non-existent PID, yum-builddep will overwrite it with its own. If it refers to an existing PID, yum-builddep will wait until that PID exits, and then overwrite it with its own.

openstack/block_storage/v3/_proxy.py.message: There's a mismatch here. This is getting all backend capabilities, yet you're expecting a capabilities parameter that corresponds to a single capability (ID or instance). Are you sure you want this parameter? If you don't, we usually name list-style methods as e.g. 'foos' where 'foo' is the resource type. So this would be simply 'capabilities', not 'get_capabilities'

Thanks for the reply!
I agree, my parameter makes no sense whatsoever. I believe after looking at [1], my parameter should be a "Specified backend to obtain volume stats and properties."

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-cinderclient/blob/f1236e09404c52b5eb3d9ba528be91d49487e08a/cinderclient/v2/capabilities.py
As above, should this be '_get'? If so, why is the resource called Capabilities (plural) instead of Capability (singular)?

Thanks for the reply!

I do believe that it still should be '_get' as it is not performing a list operation. As for the plural question, I am not 100% sure of whether or not it should be plural or not. I agree that '_get' methods are typically singular, but in this case I think there is a similar exception to the one Artem brought up previously in response to the naming scheme of the "get_limits" method [1]. Also, since the object in question in called 'capabilities', wouldn't it make sense to still have it called 'get_capabilities' in contrast to 'get_capability'? 

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/776318/5/openstack/block_storage/v3/_proxy.py

Works wonderfully. You can identify a host via 'openstack volume service list', e.g.

  | cinder-volume    | devstack-a-1@lvmdriver-1 | nova | enabled | down  | 2021-03-23T11:48:11.000000 |
  | cinder-volume    | devstack-a-2@lvmdriver-1 | nova | enabled | up    | 2021-03-23T14:45:13.000000 |
  +------------------+--------------------------+------+---------+-------+----------------------------+

With that done, comparing the output from cinderclient:

  $ cinder get-capabilities devstack-a-2@lvmdriver-1

  | Volume stats        | Value                                               |
  +---------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+

with that of openstacksdk (using this patch):

kubernetes/k8s-pod-recovery/centos/files.message:
Instead of a hardcoded list, could we instead have a directory where conf files could be written that would add to this list at runtime? ie. /etc/starlingx/k8s-post-recovery.d
So an application that needed this feature could create a file /etc/starlingx/k8s-post-recovery.d/APP_X.conf, for example, with an entry like:
namespaces=('app-x-namespace')

This script could then read all files in this directory to generate a list of namespaces to handle.

So, if we take this approach where exactly do we put the code responsible for creating the .conf files? I ask this because deployment-manager is not considered an app by starlingx ecosystem, but the monitor and openstack are indeed apps.

This could cause some cross-contamination, as vars set by each file are being set in the current environment. And now that I'm thinking about it, given that the content in this dir will be somewhat uncontrolled, it may be best to avoiding sourcing the file (as someone could put bash commands in there as well, which would get executed as whatever user is running this script, presumably root).

Rather than an array with a list, then, maybe it's safer to have this as "namespace=X", and have the code do something like:

for conf_file in ${CONF_DIR}/*.conf; do
    grep -q '^namespace=' $conf_file || continue
    SUPPORTED_NAMESPACES+=($(grep '^namespace=' $conf_file | awk -F'=' '{print $2}'))
done

element, not each

element). I'll look at fixing this in openstackdocstheme but there's nothing we can do here IMO

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message: I'm not sure what complexity this adds to the patch, but we should always validate the static resources. Some of the resources have no equivalent in OpenStack - for example, we create some extra host protection profile entries (security group rules in AIM) to allow traffic to/from the DHCP server, even though those security groups don't exist in neutron. Similarly, we should always include the common tenant, mainly because the user can't explicitly include or exclude the common tenant in ACI (i.e. there is no equivalent in OpenStack).
I'm fine keeping it this way - it just seemed more explicit that the common tenant is "special" by not making the call.

Hi Thomas,
By default, I am always including common tenant in the validation. _should_validate_tenant always allows resources from common tenant to be validated. I added that check for increasing readability.

This is just a style nit, but I would move the calls to _should_validate_neutron_resource inside each validate_<xxx> method. My thinking is that they should belong with their other qualification code (i.e. tenant scoping) - see also my comment below.

I think we should use the DB query to include any tenant scoping. That would make the DB query faster, as there would be less resources returned. This same comment applies to all the other DB queries inside the _validate_<xxx> methods. The above could be something like:

    if mgr.tenant_scope:
        query += lambda q: q.filter(
            as_db.AddressScope.project_id.in_(
                sa.bindparam('project_ids', expanding=True)))
        scopes_db = query.(mgr.actual_session).params(
                project_ids=list(mgr.tenant_scope)):
    else:
        scopes_db = query(mgr.actual_session)
    for scope_db in scopes_db:
        ....

This might be an exception to the change proposed above, since this method returns dictionaries of routers and routers connected to external networks (see other comment below), and we don't want tenancy affecting these as this mapping is not straightforward.

Ack. I am using a saparate get_routers method to return dictionaries of routers and routers connected to external network. so we can filter here as well. By using a different method, now validating router and network are mutually independent.

gbpservice/neutron/services/grouppolicy/.message: I think I left out an important piece when describing the desired workflow. The apic_aim mechanism driver maps neutron resources to AIM resources. From a user's perspective, they know about neutron resources, but they don't have to know about the AIM resources. The goal here was to allow users to scope things by the openstack project and neutron resource (network, router, subnet, security group), with the initial resource target being security groups. It looks like the scoping here is based on AIM resources instead.

Hi Thomas, thanks for the comment. 
The inconsistencies between neutron and aim db is displayed to user in terms of aim resources and user is allowed to manage each aim resources explicitly, hence I thought the user would want to resolve in terms of aim resource.
But, your point does make sense to me.
I'm a bit confused - I would have expected this to validate against the ValidationManager's self.resources list, if populated. How is that check happening?

I was looking for a reference for this in the coding/style guidelines for OpenStack, but couldn't find it. That said, from all the code I've seen in OpenStack, there seems to be an implicit convention is that class names use CamelCase, while variable and class member names use snake_case.
Done

Can't we remove these (applies for all of these mappings)? I would have expected that the AIM resources needed here were the same as the ones returned from the "_map_<resource>" methods in the mechanism driver (see https://opendev.org/x/group-based-policy/src/commit/88f0b9cdcef3c14387c226acd2e4c94e2441583a/gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drivers/apic_aim/mechanism_driver.py#L4382-L4397 for an example).

Hi Thomas, regarding using existing functions (_map_<resource>), 
The map functions (network, port)are not consistent with the validation code. If we go by these functions, then many false-positive unexpected resources will be reported, unless we change the validation code as well. For eg, in case of external network, there are aim resources such as l3out, external_network, external_subnet, vrf, Vdest, etc that are expected. An explicit mapping of resources gives a clear picture of neutron:aim resource mapping consistent with the validation code, hence I think we  should keep it this way. 


Regarding tenant and ap:
If we remove these, we will need to remove all the expect_project calls from validation code, basically remove validation of fvTenant and fvAp altogether from validation code. This will break unit-tests.

Let me know your thoughts.

I checked those mappings, they are not available for every neutron resource.Hence, I created these mappings manually by going through the validation code.
For eg: for a port, we expected erspan resources (Vdest, Vsource) which are not considered by _map_port method.

Ah - the port is my mistake. My ERSPAN patch created that method, but it's not consistent with the others. I think it would be good to keep that pattern that's used. My other point here was that I don't think we need to specify the Tenant and ApplicationProfile resources here - even though they will still be needed, we don't consider them as part of the mapping (i.e. we would cover the Tenant and ApplicationProfile mappings with the call to ensure_tenant).

nit: this can just be:
   self.aim_resources = set()
   for resource in self.neutron_resources:
       self.aim_resources.update(self.neutron_to_aim_mapping[resource])
Done
nit: looks like an extra space.
Done

Shouldn't we also check to see whether or not this falls outside the scoped tenants (i.e. not one of the tenants we're validating)? I'd also be curious of what this is - it would make sense if it were something in the common tenant, but I wouldn't expect we'd pick it up if it was from a tenant that we weren't scoping.
Done. During only resource scoping, we can encounter unexpected resources, not during tenant scoping.
Could we also check whether it's one of the scoped tenants and resources?

We *should* be able to do this - there is only one AIM resource created, which is scoped by a tenant. Which tenant to use may be complicated, because as you point out some mappings are affected by other state (e.g. networks and routers they're connected to). We could introduce a helper method here if needed. My concern is that we falsely validate a configuration, just because we skipped over a resource that really should have been validated.

I have introduced a helper function which determines whether an unexpected db instance should be handled or not. 
For networkMapping records:
For svi networks, l3out_tenant_name is used to determine tenants, else epg_tenant_name is used.

I am not sure how we can classify them at tenant level as networkMapping has multiple tenant-name available. (If we can use any one of them than it'd be possible) Hence in case scoping is done at tenant level, I am skipping deleting these, just to be on the safe side.

During only resource level scoping, we can delete any unexpected instances. 
NetworkMapping has bd_tenant_name, epg_tenant_name, l3out_tenant_name, vrf_tenant_name.
super-nit: extra space (not worth a patch re-spin though, but something to clean up in a future patch).

manifests/profile/base/cinder/backup/gcs.message: How about renaming this to "credential" . I feel the current "cinder_backup_gcs_" prefix is a bit redundant because all elements are already included in the class name.

> mostly to follow the convention I see in the puppet-cinder volume and backup backends

IIUC these naming are mostly intended to keep consistency with parameter names in cinder itself.
I think we don't need to care about that situation in puppet-tripleo which doesn't  have direct relationship with parameter names.

> but would you be OK if I named it "credentials"?

Sorry that was just my typo and I totally agree with "credentials".
My intention was to only remove prefixes and didn't intend to remove that s...

I agree much of the parameter name is redundant, mostly to follow the convention I see in the puppet-cinder volume and backup backends. The cinder_backup_gcs_credential_file parameter is an example that follows that convention.

I am happy to not blindly follow the convention in the puppet-tripleo code. However, I prefer to name the parameter "credentials" to follow the more common english usage. This is similar to the way we refer to "data" (the plural form) much more often than "datum" (the singular form). In other words, I am OK changing the parameter name, but would you be OK if I named it "credentials"?

Sorry I missed pointing this in my previous comment but can we also rename this to credential_file ?

IMO we don't need strict mapping of parameter names in puppet-tripleo, thus we can remove redundant prefixes.

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: nit: This is very descriptive, but it does make calling it a bit long-winded. Would '_collect_fk_ops' be appropriate?

Agreed it's long. I wanted it to be clear that it generates sql statements so maybe like _collect_fk_stmts? Actually, I used the word "collect" because of the modification of args, so when I change it to not, I'd likely  want to call it _get_fk_statements instead.
style nit: could you add a newline after this to help visually group things? This is a lot to absorb visually

The use of side-effects here works, but it's a little confusing and not something commonly done in Python. Rather than doing this, could we make use of return values? Something as simple as the below ought to do the trick?

  inserts = []
  deletes = []
  for fk in fk_table.foreign_keys:
      ...
      if fk_records:
          ...
          inserts.insert(0, fk_insert)
          ...
          deletes.insert(0, fk_delete)

      result = _collect_fk_inserts_and_deletes(
          metadata, conn, fk_table, fk_column, fk_records)
      inserts = result[0] + inserts
      deletes = result[1] + deletes

...or equivalent with deque - I'm not familiar with the API for that /o\ 

You could also make use of yield and just switch the order around so we go depth-first:

  for result in _collect_fk_inserts_and_deletes(
      metadata, conn, fk_table, fk_column, fk_records,
  ):
      yield result

  for fk in fk_table.foreign_keys:
      ...
      if fk_records:
          ...
          yield (insert, delete)

That makes the caller a bit weird since you'd now be iterating over the operations on a per-table basis rather than a per-operation type basis, but it's still readable:

  fk_ops = _collect_fk_inserts_and_deletes(
      metadata, conn, table, column, records)
  
  for insert_op, delete_op in fk_ops:
      ...

In any case, I think it's fair to say we do not need to rely on side effects here 😅
That's fair enough about the side effects. It took me awhile to get this working right 😆 and I'm not attached to the idea of modifying the args. Will change it.
You can remove these now. They're never accessed outside of the scope of the below if-statement where they're created

sysinv/cgts-client/cgts-client/cgtsclien.message: nit: I know our import order isn't consistent, but would be good to add these in the first section of imports which are supposed to be the external ones (i.e. line 34 in this case).

So it looks like adding 'list' here to the dict_items response in python3 may not be needed.  

data.items().sort() would have failed, but 'sorted' is supposed to be able to handle it.

example (foo.py):
data = { 'a':'a', 'b':'b', 'd':'d', 'c':'c'}
X = data.items()
print("ITEMS:                %s %s " % (X, type(X)))
X = sorted(data.items())
print("SORTED ITEMS:         %s %s" % (X, type(X)))
X = sorted(list(data.items()))
print("SORTED LIST ITEMS:    %s %s" % (X, type(X)))

python 2.7:
ITEMS:                [('a', 'a'), ('c', 'c'), ('b', 'b'), ('d', 'd')] <type 'list'>
SORTED ITEMS:         [('a', 'a'), ('b', 'b'), ('c', 'c'), ('d', 'd')] <type 'list'>
SORTED LIST ITEMS:    [('a', 'a'), ('b', 'b'), ('c', 'c'), ('d', 'd')] <type 'list'>

python 3.6.8
ITEMS:                dict_items([('a', 'a'), ('b', 'b'), ('d', 'd'), ('c', 'c')]) <class 'dict_items'>
SORTED ITEMS:         [('a', 'a'), ('b', 'b'), ('c', 'c'), ('d', 'd')] <class 'list'>
SORTED LIST ITEMS:    [('a', 'a'), ('b', 'b'), ('c', 'c'), ('d', 'd')] <class 'list'>

This is almost right. It looks like the rate limiting part of this API is really meant for API v2. To get this working, you need to modify your 'api-paste.ini' file ('/etc/cinder/api-paste.ini' on a DevStack deployment) to enable it for Cinder, changing the following:

  [composite:openstack_volume_api_v2]
  use = call:cinder.api.middleware.auth:pipeline_factory
  noauth = cors http_proxy_to_wsgi request_id faultwrap sizelimit osprofiler noauth apiv2
  keystone = cors http_proxy_to_wsgi request_id faultwrap sizelimit osprofiler authtoken keystonecontext apiv2
  keystone_nolimit = cors http_proxy_to_wsgi request_id faultwrap sizelimit osprofiler authtoken keystonecontext apiv2

  [composite:openstack_volume_api_v3]
  use = call:cinder.api.middleware.auth:pipeline_factory
  noauth = cors http_proxy_to_wsgi request_id faultwrap sizelimit osprofiler noauth apiv3
  keystone = cors http_proxy_to_wsgi request_id faultwrap sizelimit osprofiler authtoken keystonecontext apiv3
  keystone_nolimit = cors http_proxy_to_wsgi request_id faultwrap sizelimit osprofiler authtoken keystonecontext apiv3

to:

  use = call:cinder.api.middleware.auth:pipeline_factory

/COMMIT_MSG.message: It looks like this patch fixes bug 1895933 too. If I am correct, could you mention the bug?

neutron/policy.py.message:
I'm ok with this change. Thanks to bp/secure-rbac-roles implementation, we have "personas" as system-admin or project-admin.

My concern is those other many places where we still just check "if context.is_admin": https://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=if%20context.is_admin&i=nope&files=&excludeFiles=&repos=openstack/neutron

I agree that we perhaps need to revisit the usage of "context.is_admin", but I think all above usages of context.is_admin does not affect the issue fixed here.

I checked other usages.
In the first three usages of the above search result, it is part of "context if context.is_admin else context.elevated()" so the resulting context is always an admin context, so it does not matter much I think.
The usage in l3_db.py is part of _add_interface_by_port() so the API operation is already validated by the policy, so it does not directly affect the issue tackled by this patch.

The system-scoped token is used even when enforce_new_defaults is not True.
The new rules are evaluated first, so I wonderr this problem happens if a user is associated with system-scope.

enforce_new_defaults True means that deprecated rules aree not evaluated.
https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/configuration/index.html#oslo_policy.enforce_new_defaults

I still haven't got a good idea but we might need some new config option which controls whether we always evaluate policies even regardlesss of context.is_admin is True.

I think that makes sense. Since this behavior is config driven, I think we could add a unit test or two showcasing the behavior of each.

In theory, the unit tests should continue to work (so long as they don't rely on the is_admin property directly) as neutron continues to refactor/remove the is_admin check out of it's codebase in the future, right?

My understanding is that when new defaults are used we shouldn't have something like "is_admin" in the policy checks as there are many different "types" of admins, like system-admin or project-admin. Because of that in policy module we should avoid checking if context.is_admin == True and always perform rules checks. Because of that in first PS I simply removed that

    if context.is_admin:
        return True

part from here. And that worked fine in my devstack env with new roles but it caused failure of about 3000 unit tests which we will need to modify to make it really working like that.
So I'm proposing now to skip checking if context.is_admin only if enforce_new_defaults == True. That way if user wants to use new defaults it will work as it should. If user still wants to use deprecated rules, it will simply return True quickly here. And that is really correct behaviour IMO. Lets see e.g. "GET /agents" call:

- when enforce_new_defaults == True - it has rule SYSTEM_READER and scope_types = ['system'] which means that project admin can't list agents, only system admin/reader persona can do it. Now in the code in case of call made by PROJECT_ADMIN persona, context.is_admin == True so without that patch such person would be able to list agents but with this patch not.

- now, when enforce_new_defaults == False - we should also respect deprecated rule for "GET /agents" which is base.RULE_ADMIN_ONLY - and that is true for both system admin and project admin personas, so in such case we can check if context.is_admin == True and don't perform all checks in such case.

I hope my understanding of that is correct and that I explained it clearly :)

Thanks for the detail explanation and it makes sense. I was a bit confused when I wrote my last commet.

The most important point is to ensure that PROJECT_ADMIN cannot get access by "context.is_admin" check here in case of enforce_new_defaults == True.
In case of enforce_new_defaults == False, both SYSTEM_READER/SYSTEM_ADMIN/PROJECT_ADMIN can access the API. For SYSTEM_READER/SYSTEM_ADMIN, the normal policy check below is applied. For PROJECT_ADMIN, we can keep the access via context.is_admin check here.

I believe I got the full context. Thanks.

neutron/tests/unit/test_policy.py.message:
Once the system scope becomes the default, "admin" role no longer plays this role.
Perhaps we need more work than just setting "admin" role automatically.

I know this is a workaround to handle our current tests which assume "admin" role for system admin.
I am fine with this workaround now.

The key point of this test is when project_admin_ctx contains "admin" role this check always succeeds regardless of the policy rule evaluated, so this UT can be simplified more, but I am okay with this version.
